      <p>
    
      <a class="Link " href="https://www.dl-online.com/latest" data-cms-ai="0">DETROIT LAKES</a>
    
      — Richard Lee Washington, 71, of Detroit Lakes has been charged in Becker County District Court with three felony counts of domestic assault and one count of felony fifth-degree drugs.</p><p>He is accused of assaulting a woman on various occasions from Dec. 19 through Jan. 7, by doing things like hitting her with his cane, stomping on her foot, cutting her arm with a knife and striking her on the knee and also on the head with a hammer.</p>
    
      
    
      
    
      <p>The woman and Washington have shared a romantic, sexual relationship in the past, and she stated that she had allowed herself to be his "punching bag" for too long, according to the criminal complaint.</p><p>He was pulled over and arrested on the assault allegations on Jan. 10 in Detroit Lakes. The arresting officer found an orange flare gun under the driver's seat with two 12-gauge flares attached to it.</p><p>Washington’s jacket allegedly was found to contain two baggies of cocaine, weighing a total of 6.63 grams with packaging.</p><p>Washington has two prior qualified domestic violence-related convictions from 2024, and a pending case alleging felony violation of a harassment restraining order. In that matter, his conditions of release direct that he is to have no contact with the victim, according to court records.</p><p>On Jan. 13, bail or bond with no conditions was set at $100,000 or $50,000 bond, or $5,000 cash bail with conditions that include no contact with the woman. The next day, he posted $5,000 cash bail and was released.</p><p>His next court appearance is set for Feb. 9 before District Judge Gretchen Thilmony.</p>

                            <h2>Becker County man accused of violating predatory offender law</h2>
                        
                    
                
            </p>
        </div>
    
      <p>Duane Lawrence Fineday Jr., 36, address unknown, has been charged in Becker County District Court with two felony counts of violating the predatory offender law by failing to register his current address.</p>
    
      
    
      <p>According to court records, on March 18, 2025, a Detroit Lakes police officer went to an apartment building to verify with the manager if anyone was living in a certain apartment. They confirmed nobody was living there.</p>
    
      
    
      <p>The address was listed as Fineday’s primary address, and he is required to register as a predatory offender until 2041, based on a criminal sexual conduct adjudication of delinquency in September of 2006 in Hubbard County.</p><p>The Detroit Lakes apartment was supposed to have been Fineday’s address since Nov. 6, 2024, as listed in a Bureau of Criminal Apprehension registration packet. No updated form or change of address has been received, according to court records.</p><p>Fineday has had an active arrest warrant since Nov. 21, 2024. Efforts to locate Fineday through family members at previously listed addresses were unsuccessful. He has two active misdemeanor warrants for failing to appear at court hearings in April and July 2025, and he has not had contact with law enforcement. A new arrest warrant was issued Jan. 16 in Becker County District Court.</p>

      <div class="Enhancement">
            <p class="Enhancement-item">
                
                
                    
                        
                            <h2>Bagley man sentenced on drug charge</h2>
                        
                    
                
            </p>
        </div>
    
      <p>Patrick Michael Thompson, 31, of rural Bagley has been sentenced in Becker County District Court for felony fifth-degree drugs.</p><p>According to court records, at about 3 a.m. on Sept. 14, 2025, he was a passenger in a vehicle pulled over on County Highway 34 by Becker County deputies because of a faulty brake light.</p>
    
      
    
      
    
      <p>He was arrested on a Mahnomen County warrant. A search of the vehicle turned up a small vial with a white powdery substance inside of it, wedged between the passenger seat and center console area, where Thompson had been sitting.</p><p>The small glass vial field-tested positive for fentanyl and weighed 6.86 grams with packaging, according to court records.</p><p>On Jan. 6, District Judge Michelle Lawson issued a stay of adjudication. Successful completion of probation will result in a dismissal.</p><p>Thompson was sentenced to 53 days in the Becker County Jail, with credit for 53 days served. He was fined $500 plus $75 in court fees. He was also ordered to complete a comprehensive assessment and cognitive skills training, and follow the recommendations, including aftercare, and was placed on supervised probation for five years.<br></p>
